results.title: Describing an incident
results.brief_description: A group of students describe an incident. In the first instance a poor description is given - a girl trying to describe how a friend’s father nearly missed a train, wanders off into irrelevant detail and fails to capture interest. Another girl, describing the same incident, creates interest with an ordered and well-presented account.

results.title: Descendant of Genghiz Khan = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Better known under the title “Storm over Asia”, this exotic film is a remarkable drama of British Imperial intrigue in Mongolia in the civil war days of 1920. Valeri Inkijinov plays a young Mongolian trapper ostracised from his village after he is cheated out of a valuable fox fur by a European trader. Becoming a Soviet partisan, the trapper is thrust into prominence when it is learned that he is descended from Genghis Khan. The occupying English army (identified as the White Russian army in foreign prints of the film) puts the trapper in charge of a puppet Mongolian government. By film’s end, however, the “puppet” has cut the strings in a spectacular fashion. In Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: Desalting the seas
results.creator_credit: Oak Ridge National Laboratory and Stephen Sinichak
results.brief_description: Describes the various methods of purifying salt water through the use of nuclear energy, with particular emphasis on nuclear electric desalting plants which produce large amounts of power as well as pure water. Describes the growing shortage of water in a famine-threatened world of expanding population, and ways to combat this.

results.title: Derwent runs down to the sea
results.creator_credit: Linda Taylor, Mobil Oil Australia, Tasfilm Productions and Don Anderson
results.brief_description: Shows a canoe trip along the River Derwent from its source in the highlands at Lake St Clair in Tasmania. Explains the river’s importance in supplying water for agriculture, transport and power.

results.title: Dermatitis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Safety”.
Dermatitis is a problem in many industries. This film shows how dermatitis is caused and how it can be avoided. Dermatitis in the home is also briefly discussed.

results.title: Deregulation & monetary policy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
An examination of how monetary policy has operated in Australia in the 1980’s, presented by Richard Bluck of Melbourne College of Advanced Education. Covers how monetary policy operated in the old regulated financial sector and now under deregulation; review of major institutional and other changes; reasons for deregulation and its implications for macro-economic management of the Australian economy. Worksheets are included with the video.

results.title: Depression. Addiction
results.creator_credit: Annie Moore, Michael Custance, Discovery Networks Europe and B-line Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Alternative”.
This episode of the fifteen part television series on complementary health focuses on two separate segments: “Depression” (and stress) and “Addiction”. In the first segment on depression, a brief definition and explanation of how and why this emotional illness can cause so much grief, physically and psychically. Explains ‘Melancholic’ and ‘Atypical’ depression and the fact that stress can also be attributed and/or linked to depression. Suggests that learning a better response to depression rather than just trying to cure it would be far more beneficial. By using case studies, the following areas of therapy are discussed and demonstrated: Hypnotherapy; Colour therapy; Reflexology and flower remedy therapy; the Journey therapy. The second segment deals with various forms of addiction with a brief explanation of why some people suffer from this disease (10% of the population have addictive or compulsive behavior problems) and why others don’t. Through various case studies, it covers cannabis, food and alcohol addiction with discussion and demonstration of the following therapies: Homeopathic and Shamanic practice; Hypnotherapy and nutrition; Chinese medicine including acupuncture, Qi Gong and herbal therapy. Commentary by Dilly Barlow.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Annie Moore, Michael Custance, Discovery Networks Europe and B-line Productions
